content: The "True American Heroes Act of 2002" may be cited as the Act. It includes provisions for Congressional Gold Medals for government workers who responded to the attacks on the World Trade Center and perished. The "True American Heroes Act of 2002" authorizes the presentation of Congressional Gold Medals to officers, emergency workers, and government employees who responded to the 9/11 attacks on the World Trade Center and perished, with arrangements made by the Speaker of the House and the President pro tempore of the Senate. The "True American Heroes Act of 2002" authorizes the Secretary of the Treasury to strike gold medals with suitable emblems for valor and heroism of 9/11 responders. Recipients will be determined in consultation with relevant authorities, and duplicates will be made for display in respective offices. The "True American Heroes Act of 2002" authorizes the display of gold medals for 9/11 responders in various offices and stations, including those of key officials and emergency services heads in New York City. The "True American Heroes Act of 2002" authorizes the display of gold medals for 9/11 responders in various offices and stations. The Secretary may strike and sell duplicates in bronze of the gold medal at a price to cover costs. It is recommended that the medals be struck at the United States Mint at West Point, New York. CONGRESSIONAL GOLD MEDALS AUTHORIZED FOR UNITED AIRLINES FLIGHT 93 PASSENGERS WHO RESISTED HIJACKERS. On September 11, 2001, United Airlines Flight 93 was hijacked by terrorists and crashed near Shanksville, Pennsylvania after passengers resisted the hijackers. The leaders of the resistance aboard United Airlines Flight 93 demonstrated exceptional bravery, valor, and patriotism, potentially saving lives and important symbols of freedom. Congressional Gold Medals are authorized for passengers and crew who aided in resisting the hijackers. The Secretary of the Treasury will strike gold medals with suitable designs, emblems, and inscriptions for individuals who aided in resisting hijackers on United Airlines Flight 93. Duplicate bronze medals may also be struck and sold at a price to cover production costs. SEC. 103. Congressional Gold Medals for government workers who responded to the attacks on the Pentagon and perished. In recognition of the bravery and self-sacrifice of government workers who responded to the 9/11 attacks on the Pentagon, a gold medal will be presented to their next of kin. The design of the medal will be determined by the Secretary of the Treasury. The Secretary of the Treasury will determine the number of medals and recipients after consulting with relevant officials. SEC. 104. NATIONAL MEDALS. The medals struck under this title are national medals for purposes of chapter 51 of title 31, United States Code. The Congress acknowledges the tragic events of September 11, 2001, where over 6,000 lives were lost in terrorist attacks in New York City, at the Pentagon, and in Pennsylvania. Emergency personnel responded heroically, and the nation united in support of the victims and their families. The civilized world stands against such cowardly acts of terrorism. The Congress acknowledges the tragic events of September 11, 2001, where over 6,000 lives were lost in terrorist attacks in New York City, at the Pentagon, and in Pennsylvania. Emergency personnel responded heroically, and the nation united in support of the victims and their families. The minting of coins in commemoration of the Spirit of America will pay tribute to the countless heroes who risked their lives during the attacks and in their aftermath, and to a united people whose belief in freedom, justice, and democracy has never wavered. SEC. 202. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $50 gold coins weighing 1 ounce with 91.67% gold, $1 silver coins weighing 26.73 grams with 90% silver, and half dollar clad coins. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue half dollar clad coins weighing 11.34 grams with a diameter of 1.205 inches, following specific specifications. Additionally, the number of gold coins minted and issued will be determined by adding 25,000 to a number determined by the Secretary in consultation with relevant authorities. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint $50 coins to honor innocent individuals killed in the 9/11 attacks. The coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. Only metals from natural deposits in the US or its territories can be used for minting. Special treatment is allowed under exigent circumstances. The Congress acknowledges the effectiveness of limitations on commemorative coins to stabilize markets and maximize demand. Special treatment is permitted under exigent circumstances, such as the events of September 11, 2001. The Congress acknowledges the need for special treatment in producing commemorative coins to raise funds for the victims of the September 11, 2001, attacks, exempting them from existing limitations. The design of coins minted under this title shall symbolize the events of September 11, 2001, with specific inscriptions and symbols. The Secretary will select the design in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts. Coins minted under this title shall be issued in uncirculated quality, except for $50 gold coins which shall be issued in proof quality. Only 1 facility of the United States Mint may be used to strike any particular quality of the coins, except for half dollar coins which can be struck at any number of facilities. The Secretary will commence issuing coins as soon as possible after the enactment of this Act, and will not issue any coins after the end of the 1-year period. Coins shall not be issued after the 1-year period from the date of first issuance. Coins shall not be issued after the 1-year period from the date of first issuance. Sale of coins is regulated under SEC. 205. The Secretary sells coins at a price including face value, surcharges, and design costs. Bulk sales are offered at a discount, and prepaid orders receive a reasonable discount. Gold coins are exempt from certain regulations. The Secretary offers discounts on bulk sales and prepaid orders for coins. A 50 dollar gold coin will be issued free of charge to the next of kin or personal representative of individuals identified under a specific section. The presentation will be arranged by the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President Pro Tempore of the Senate on behalf of Congress. SEC. 206. SURCHARGES ON SALE OF COINS. The Secretary of the Treasury imposes surcharges on the sale of minted coins to cover production costs. Surcharges range from $5 to $100 per coin, depending on the denomination. Excess proceeds are used to cover production costs of all coins issued under this title. The Secretary of the Treasury imposes surcharges on minted coins to cover production costs. Excess proceeds not recovered from bronze medal sales are transferred to a fund for victims of the September 11, 2001 tragedies. The House of Representatives passed the bill on July 22, 2002.
